docs.text: Turn off AI If you don't want to use AI, you should be able to turn it off. Over the past few years, many technology companies have added artificial intelligence (AI) features to their products, and they're very keen for you to use them. But if you don't want to use them, you might find instructions on this site that show you how to turn them off. This site can't cover every product or service available, or keep up with the current rate at which AI features are being added. If you're looking for something that isn't listed here, don't give up. You can search somewhere else or contact the product or service's support. If want to turn off AI in a product or service and it won't let you, your choice is then whether or not to continue using that product or service. There are always alternatives. Just check that the alternative provides more end user choice before you make the switch. Open Source Alternatives To Proprietary Software AlternativeTo European alternatives for digital products What do we mean by AI? This site specifically relates to generative AI that produces text, images, audio, or video. These are AI services that were trained on large amounts of example content, and then reconstruct an amalgamated output in response to a prompt. For example, if someone asks for a picture of a cat wearing a clown hat, as long as the example content included pictures of cats, clown hats, and creatures wearing hats, the service can create an amalgamtion that matches the prompt. The field of AI includes a much broader range of technologies that have been in use for decades, and many products that are now marketed as AI weren't considered AI a few years ago. For more information, refer to What is AI, how does it work and why are some people concerned about it? from the BBC. For even more information, refer to Understanding the different types of artificial intelligence from IBM.
docs.title: Turn off AI

docs.text: How to avoid consuming AI Not consuming AI means not accessing text, images, audio, or video that was produced by generative AI. Use the articles in this section to learn how you can avoid consuming AI in a specific product or service. The following are some general guidelines on how to avoid consuming AI. Searching before 2023 Generative AI content began to emerge around 2022 to 2023. If you use a search that includes a date filter, you can restrict the search to before 2023 to filter out almost all of the correctly classified AI content. This is a drastic option, because you'll exclude all of the latest information. However, if the thing you're searching for existed before 2023, you might still find the result you need.
docs.title: How to avoid consuming AI

docs.title: How to avoid consuming AI

docs.text: DuckDuckGo A search engine that promises privacy and the protection of personal data. You can go to the DuckDuckGo website to perform a search, or configure your browser to use DuckDuckGo as the default search engine. Turning off AI search summaries AI summaries are shown on the search results page by default. To turn them off, complete the following steps: On the search results page, in the Search Assist panel, select the gear icon. In the How often do you want to see Search Assist answers? window, select Never , and then select Save .
docs.title: DuckDuckGo

docs.title: DuckDuckGo

docs.title: Turning off AI search summaries

docs.text: YouTube The video streaming site owned by Google. The site provides a variety of AI tools and reports that 92% of their creators are using generative AI tools . The site is also allegedly applying AI filtering to uploaded videos without the creators' explicit consent. Searching for videos uploaded before 2023 You can use the standard strategy of searching for videos that were uploaded before generative AI was widely used. When you perform a search, include before:2023-01-01 in the search field. Subscribing You've likely been asked to "like and subscribe" when watching videos on YouTube, but as well as helping the creators, it can help you avoid AI. If you subscribe only to channels that you trust to not use AI generated content, you can go to https://www.youtube.com/feed/subscriptions to see only their videos. Altered content When someone uploads a video, they can mark it as including Altered Content . This is essentially useless for the following reasons: It only applies if "...content is altered or synthetic and seems real". So shrimp Jesus, or other obviously fake content probably wouldn't need to be flagged. There isn't any way to filter out videos marked in this way. The only indication is a label added to the video's description . The person that uploads a video has to voluntarily select the checkbox.
docs.title: YouTube

docs.text: Android The operating system used on many phones and tablets. There's a wide variety of device configurations and customised versions of Android. So, unfortunately, the instructions on this page aren't guarenteed to work for your device. Turning off the virtual assistant shortcut On many Android devices, if you hold the power button for a few seconds, you start the virtual assistant. Most recently, this is Google's AI agent, Gemini. To change what happens when you hold the power button, complete the following steps: Go to your phone's settings. You might have a Settings app. Alternatively, swipe down from the top-right corner of your device, and then select the gear icon. You might need to swipe down twice. Search for each of the settings listed in the table. If you see an exact match, select the search result, and the follow the additional steps: Setting Additional steps gesture shortcuts Select Launch Google Assistant , and then turn off the setting. button navigation Turn off the Hold Home for Assistant setting. long press Select Long press , and then select Power off menu . Press and hold the power button Select the Power menu option instead of the Digital assistant option. Uninstall Gemini Gemini is Google's AI app that replaces Google Assistant. It might be preinstalled on your device or have been installed as part of a system update. You can uninstall it in the same way that you would any other app. If you're unsure how to do that on your device, try the following: Go to your phone's settings. You might have a Settings app. Alternatively, swipe down from the top-right corner of your device, and then select the gear icon. You might need to swipe down twice. Tap Apps . Tap Manage apps . In the list of installed apps, tap Gemini . On the App info page, tap Uninstall . In the confirmation prompt, tap * ok .
docs.title: Android

You can uninstall it in the same way that you would any other app. If you're unsure how to do that on your device, try the following: Go to your phone's settings. You might have a Settings app. Alternatively, swipe down from the top-right corner of your device, and then select the gear icon. You might need to swipe down twice. Tap Apps . Tap Manage apps . In the list of installed apps, tap Gemini . On the App info page, tap Uninstall . In the confirmation prompt, tap * ok .
docs.title: Uninstall Gemini

docs.text: Bing The search engine from Microsoft. AI generated summaries might appear on the search results page. There is no way to turn them off.
docs.title: Bing

docs.text: The search engine from Microsoft. AI generated summaries might appear on the search results page. There is no way to turn them off.
docs.title: Bing

docs.text: Google search AI summaries might appear on the search results page. Using the -AI search term The easiest way to both remove AI summaries on the search results page and AI results is as follows: Include -AI in your search. For example, country with the longest border -AI . Filtering to websites only By filtering the search results to just websites, you can remove the AI summaries. This also removes other widgets, like People also ask , as well as video and image suggestions. To apply the filter, do the following: Add &udm=14 to the end of the address after you perform a search. For example, https://www.google.com/search?q=country+with+the+longest+border&udm=14 . To make search more convenient, you can use udm14.org . If you perform a search there, it redirects you to a Google search with the udm filter applied.
docs.title: Google search

docs.title: Google search

docs.text: itch.io A marketplace for indie games and game assets. No AI tag People can tag their project to indicate they've "...not using generative AI their creative process." To view the list of projects that have been tagged as not using generative AI, go to https://itch.io/games/tag-no-ai .
docs.title: itch.io

docs.text: A marketplace for indie games and game assets.

docs.text: Steam The game markeplace and distribution platform used by both indie developers and large publishers. Using SteamDB to avoid AI Steam requires publishers to label games that include AI generated content, and to explain how AI was used. This disclosure is shown in the game's description on its Steam store page. However, you can't use the AI content disclosure to filter games on the Steam site. For that, you'll need to use an independent cataloging site: SteamDB. Go to https://steamdb.info/instantsearch/ . In the Search tags field, enter ai . Hover over the AI Content Disclosed tag, and then select exclude .
docs.title: Steam

docs.text: The game markeplace and distribution platform used by both indie developers and large publishers.
docs.title: Steam

In the Search tags field, enter ai . Hover over the AI Content Disclosed tag, and then select exclude .
docs.title: Using SteamDB to avoid AI

docs.text: X (aka Twitter) Grok is the AI service from X, which famously referred to itself as MechHitler . To mute Grok so that you don't see its posts, complete the following steps: Go to https://x.com/grok . Select the three dots (elipses) button, and then select Mute from the menu that appears.
docs.title: X (aka Twitter)

docs.title: X (aka Twitter)

docs.text: How to avoid feeding AI Not feeding AI means not providing your text, images, audio, or video to be used as training data for generative AI. Use the articles in this section to learn how you can avoid feeding AI when you use a specific product or service.
docs.title: How to avoid feeding AI

docs.text: Not feeding AI means not providing your text, images, audio, or video to be used as training data for generative AI. Use the articles in this section to learn how you can avoid feeding AI when you use a specific product or service.
docs.title: How to avoid feeding AI

docs.text: Facebook This page explains how to prevent your posts on Facebook from being used to feed AI. Warning: You need to opt out. Meta, who own Facebook, state that they "use public information on Meta Products to develop and improve generative AI models for our AI at Meta features and experiences". To prevent Meta from using your public information to feed AI, you need to submit an objection. How to submit an objection Go to https://www.facebook.com/privacy/genai Scroll down to and expand the Your right to object section. Select Learn more and submit requests here . on the Data subject rights for third-party information used for AI at Meta page, select the checkbox. Complete the form that appears. Note: You must enter at least 25 characters in the Relevant prompts field, even if you have not used the Meta AI chatbot. You must also provide an explanation in the Additional context field. Select Send . This site sends a code to your email address to verify your identity. Copy the copy from the email into the Confirm your email address panel, and then select Confirm .
docs.title: Facebook

Select Learn more and submit requests here . on the Data subject rights for third-party information used for AI at Meta page, select the checkbox. Complete the form that appears. Note: You must enter at least 25 characters in the Relevant prompts field, even if you have not used the Meta AI chatbot. You must also provide an explanation in the Additional context field. Select Send . This site sends a code to your email address to verify your identity. Copy the copy from the email into the Confirm your email address panel, and then select Confirm .
docs.title: How to submit an objection

docs.text: YouTube Google, the owner of YouTube, allegedly used YouTube videos to train AI services without the creators' consent. Although, aparently they weren't the only ones. For more information, refer to Google is training its AI tools on YouTube videos: These creators aren't happy . To check if your YouTube videos have been used to train AI, refer to Search the YouTube Videos Secretly Powering Generative AI For more information about the use of AI on YouTube, refer to Your data and using AI features on YouTube .
docs.title: YouTube

docs.text: Google, the owner of YouTube, allegedly used YouTube videos to train AI services without the creators' consent. Although, aparently they weren't the only ones. For more information, refer to Google is training its AI tools on YouTube videos: These creators aren't happy . To check if your YouTube videos have been used to train AI, refer to Search the YouTube Videos Secretly Powering Generative AI For more information about the use of AI on YouTube, refer to Your data and using AI features on YouTube .
docs.title: YouTube

docs.text: Images If you upload an image to a website or social medial platform, it might be used to train AI. This might be done without your consent and in contravention of the law. The Glaze Project provides "...tools that artists can use to disrupt unauthorized AI training on their work...". They have two main tools: Glaze : Attepts to modify your images so that AI can't be trained to copy your artistic style. Nightshade : Attempts to modify your images so if they're used to train AI, they'll "poison" that AI: meaning they'll negatively affect the images generated by the AI. You can control how much your images are modified.
docs.title: Images

docs.text: If you upload an image to a website or social medial platform, it might be used to train AI. This might be done without your consent and in contravention of the law. The Glaze Project provides "...tools that artists can use to disrupt unauthorized AI training on their work...". They have two main tools: Glaze : Attepts to modify your images so that AI can't be trained to copy your artistic style. Nightshade : Attempts to modify your images so if they're used to train AI, they'll "poison" that AI: meaning they'll negatively affect the images generated by the AI. You can control how much your images are modified.
docs.title: Images

docs.text: X (aka Twitter) To ask X not to share your data with other companies, or use it to train their AI chatbot, Grok, complete the following steps: Go to x.com. From the menu on the left-hand side, select More and then select Settings and privacy . From the Settings menu, select Privacy and safety . Scroll down the page to the Data sharing and personalization section. Select Grok & Third-party Collaborators . In the Grok & Third-party Collaborators , clear all checkboxes.
docs.title: X (aka Twitter)

Scroll down the page to the Data sharing and personalization section. Select Grok & Third-party Collaborators . In the Grok & Third-party Collaborators , clear all checkboxes.
docs.title: X (aka Twitter)
